Rouisco Pais, 1096 Lisboa Codex, Portugal Received 2 October 1995: accepted 29 February 1996 Abstract The effect of doping N'M004 with increasing Cs concentrations (1, 3 and 6%), on the crystalline structure, chemical nature and catalytic behaviour for the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane, was studied. The atomic ratio Mo/Ni = 1 and the cesium concentration were checked by several techniques (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, atomic absorption, inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy). The structural study of the a- and -phases was carried out by high temperature X-ray diffraction and showed that Cs does not affect the molybdate structure at room temperature. However it makes the transition from a- to phase by heating difficult. Cs remains on the catalyst surface blocking pores and reducing BET surface area. The acid and basic natures of the catalysts were studied by NH, and CO, temperature programmed desorption, respectively. The formation of nitrogenated compounds during the NH3-TPD was observed. C02-TPD shows an increase in the catalyst basicity with Cs doping, but overdoping was observed for the 6% Cs-NiMo04 catalyst. The catalytic tests showed a decrease of activity with the Cs content. In both the a- and phases the selectivity to dehydrogenation products increases with the Cs contents, but tends to decrease for the 6% Cs-NiMo04, due to the overdoping effect. This effect in the a-phase and the j3-phase stabilisation in the catalyst with higher Cs contents, contributes to an increase of the activity normalised to surface area. Keywords: Oxidation; Dehydrogenation; Nickel molybdates; Butane; Promoters 1. Introduction It is well known that NiMo04 may have three different structures, but, only two of them are stable at atmospheric pressure [1]. It is stabilised in tetrahedral coordination (phase) at high temperature and cannot be quenched to ambient temperature. The catalytic activity of both phases was studied by several researchers. However, while Itenberg [2] found that both phases present similar activity and selectivity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane into butadiene, it is generally accepted [1,3] that the a-phase is more 314 F.J. Maldonado-Har et al. / Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical Ill (1996) 313-323 active and the phase is more selective for this kind of alkane reactions. New preparation methods using organic salts have recently been tested in order to induce a greater stabilization of (3-phase at room temperature [4] for obtaining better selectivities and to avoid the continuous heating required to maintain the catalyst in its configuration. The catalytic behaviour of the NiMo04 is not only influenced by the crystalline structure. The chemical nature of catalyst surface (acidity/basicity) also influences the activity and product distribution with oxide-based catalysts [5,6]. On the other hand, alkali metals used as promoters also affect the activity and selectivity of the catalyst according to the nature of the promoter ion [3,7]. No papers were found concerning the effect of alkaline cations on physicochemical properties of the Ni-Mo-O system. However, a few papers studied these aspects for other catalytic systems, such as V205-Ti02 [8,9] or M003-Ti02 [10-12], including active ones for the dehydrogenation of alkanes [13]. It is therefore of great interest to study the structural and chemical aspects of NiMo04 not yet clarified, the changes that the cesium deposition causes in them, as well as the relationship between the chemical and physical properties and the activity/ selectivity of these catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane. 2. Experimental An unsupported a-NiMo04 catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation reaction according the method described by Mazzocchia et al. [14] with a Mo/Ni atomic ratio of 1. Cesium doped catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation of the a-NiMo04 over about 15 h at 60, using cesium nitrate; the liquid to solid ratio was 10 by weight. The impregnated sample was filtered and dried at 120 for 4 h and finally calcined in air for 2 h at 550. The characterization of the prepared catalysts was carried out by Inductively Coupled Plasma Spectroscopy (ICP), Atomic Absorption (AA), XRD, IR and XPS. Experimental details can be found elsewhere [3]. All the catalysts had an atomic ratio Mo/Ni = 1 and a cesium surface concentration of 1, 3 and 6%. The surface areas of all catalysts were determined by the nitrogen BET method. An attempt was made to estimate the surface areas of 0phase catalysts by quenching them after the thermal treatment required to produce the hase, although this phase cannot be completely stabilized at room temperature as shown by the XRD experiments. The structural study of both a- and phases was carried out by XRD in a Rigaku apparatus using the Cu Ka radiation (Ni filter) from 10 to 50 at 2min. The spectra were recorded at 21 for the a-phase. The activation to phase was made in situ with air flow, heating the sample at 20/min up to 710 and maintaining this temperature for 10 min before recording the spectrum [ 1 ]. The acidity/basicity of the catalyst's surface was studied by NH3 and COZ TPD, respectively. The NH 3-TPD experiments were performed only for some samples adsorbing NH 3 at 30 because formation of nitrogenated compounds was observed. The C02-TPD experiments were carried out adsorbing COZ at 30 and 250. The catalyst was pretreated by heating the sample in He flow up to 550 to clean the surface, but avoiding the transition to phase. One previous experiment carried out in He flow up to 650 showed that between 550 and 650 the detector signal is negligible. In both cases about 0.3 g of the catalysts were saturated in NH3 or COZ at the corresponding temperature and then desorbed by heating at 10/min in a He flow of 1 cm3/s, with on-line gas analysis performed with the TC detector of a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph. The catalytic experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed, continuous flow tubular quartz reactor (I.D. 20 mm; length 600 mm) with a F.J. Maldonado-Har et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical H1 (1996) 313-323 coaxially centered thermocouple. The catalyst charge was 0.3 g mixed with quartz in a volume ratio of 1:2 catalyst to quartz. This catalyst charge was chosen for always having differential conversions. All the experiments were performed at atmospheric pressure. The feed was a mixture of butane, oxygen and nitrogen with molar ratio of 4/9/87 and the contact time was equivalent to W/F = 12 g - h/molbutane. The catalytic tests were performed between 375 and 575 for a-phase and 425-600 for (3-phase. The phase catalysts were formed in situ by heating a-phase catalysts at 710 in air flow for 10 min, and then cooling to the predetermined temperature. The stability of the phase was checked throughout the temperature range used. Blank runs proved that under the experimental conditions used the homogeneous reactions can be neglected. Analyses of reactants and products were carried out by an on-line Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph with two columns: (i) molecular sieve 13X (60-80 mesh, 2 m X 1 /8 in. stainless steel); (ii) 33% dimethylsulpholane on Chromosorb P (60-80 mesh, 6 m X 1/8 in.). Conclusions It has been confirmed by HTXRD measurements that both oc- and phases of nickel molybdate are stable in the reaction temperature range used for the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane. The doping of NiMo04 with cesium does not produce structural changes in the catalyst at room temperature but it restrains the ato phase transition, especially at high concen- trations of promoter (3 and 6%), for which only 50% transition was achieved. Alkali promoter remains essentially on the catalyst surface, blocking the catalyst pores, thus decreasing the catalyst surface area as the Cs concentration is raised, both for a- and phases. C02-TPD measurements with the promoted catalysts evidence that catalyst basicity increases with respect to the unpromoted N'M004. However, a basicity decrease is noticed for the 6% Cs-ot-NiM004 due to overdoping. Such properties of the catalysts are in agreement with the results of the catalytic tests. The catalytic activity decreases for both phases following the sequence: unpromoted > 1% Cs > 3% Cs > 6% Cs. The same trend is observed for a-phase when activity is normalized to surface area. The phase shows a minimum at 1% Cs and an increase at higher cesium concentrations. This increase in surface normalized activity possibly emanates from stabilization of a-phase and overdoping. The C4's formation is favoured by the cesium presence although in the case of 6% Cs-NiM004 the overdoping leads to an increase of the CO,, selectivity. The effect of doping NiMoO4 with increasing Cs concentrations (1, 3 and 6%), on the crystalline structure, chemical nature and catalytic behaviour for the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane, was studied. The atomic ratio Mo/Ni = 1 and the cesium concentration were checked by several techniques (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, atomic absorption, inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy). The structural study of the α- and β-phases was carried out by high temperature X-ray diffraction and showed that Cs does not affect the molybdate structure at room temperature. However it makes the transition from α- to β-phase by heating difficult. Cs remains on the catalyst surface blocking pores and reducing BET surface area. The acid and basic natures of the catalysts were studied by NH3 and CO2 temperature programmed desorption, respectively. The formation of nitrogenated compounds during the NH3-TPD was observed. CO2-TPD shows an increase in the catalyst basicity with Cs doping, but overdoping was observed for the 6% CsNiMoO4 catalyst. The catalytic tests showed a decrease of activity with the Cs content. In both the α- and β-phases the selectivity to dehydrogenation products increases with the Cs contents, but tends to decrease for the 6% CsNiMoO4, due to the overdoping effect. This effect in the α-phase and the β-phase stabilisation in the catalyst with higher Cs contents, contributes to an increase of the activity normalised to surface area.
